column17:
•        Thank you so much for hosting this! My child LOVED it. He brought the photos from it into his first grade class and presented on light, the eclipse, telescopes, and the northern lights the next day.
•        I really appreciated the opportunity both to hear from astrophysicists and look through the telescope!
•        My family and I had a fantastic experience.
•        Both looking through the telescope and attending the presentation were awesome. Great for adults and kids.
•        It was great for my son and a nice family event. Particularly the explanations by the graduate students.
•        Loved the addition of the CIERA presentation. My family and I are still talking about it today.
•        I learned a lot!  Loved how the presentation was about recent activities.
•        The program was truly interesting and family friendly

column2: NASA CoS Visit to CPS Schools
column4: The Illinois Space Grant Consortium sent NASA’s Langley Chief of Staff, Andy Carnell our way to help him reach some local students. Ashley Walter (Baxter Center) and James Schottelkotte coordinated his visit to two southside Chicago Public Schools
column6: Wadsworth STEM Elementary School; South Shore International College Prep; Chicago south side.
column13: K12 Students, Underrepresented Group in STEM
column17:
“It was great! Mr. Carnell was really engaging and interesting and the kids seemed to enjoy! CPS folks and teachers really loved it!” - Ashley Walter of NU
"A few adults were listening to the students' side conversations about the dirt on Mars and moving to Venus.  The future aerospace engineers, scientists, accountants, and creatives were in awe, and the educators were too.  I also received a follow-up message from a South Shore student who informed me that NASA was listed as the best federal government job for ten years, and he wanted me to send the internship link so he could find out why.  The student's e-mail speaks volumes to the power of one visit and how "Dr. C's" presence shifted his career trajectory and ignited a curiosity, confirming the "why" we do this  STEM work. " - Carmen Mahon of CPS
column19: Heidi Bjerke (ISGC), hbjerke2@illinois.edu; Carmen Mahon (CPS), camahon@cps.edu; Andrew Carnell (NASA Langley), andrew.m.carnell@nasa.gov;
column20: Heidi brought this opportunity from Andy C to Mel Ulmer, who brought it to James. James worked with Ashley to connect with CPS schools. Will connect with Heidi to chat about future opportunities. Carmen will be a good resource to equitably distribute visits amongst CPS.
column21: Share this in the newsletter

column17:
“When the guest speakers from CIERA came in, I was so invested in their presentation and the activity they had us do. Thanks to them, I’m really inspired to explore and research more about astrophysics and astronomy.”
“Thanks to the program, I’m going to invest my time to research more careers in STEM. At first, I was sort of iffy about pursing something in STEM, but this experience changed my perspective on things. “
“Meeting with the guest speakers was the most helpful. It was nice to get exposed to the different career paths that I could possibly take, and it was nice to hear how the guest speaker’s journeys. Because of the speakers, I feel like I have somewhat of a grasp on what I would like to pursue in the future.”
“Could I have the emails of the astronomers? Especially Elena’s since she was the one with our group :)”

column4: Collaborative event with Dearborn Observatory. Public viewing of Lunar Eclipse atop the Segal Visitors Center garage. 2 telescopes from Dearborn + Lunar phases activity.
column6: Top Floor Segal Visitors Center Parking Garage. Evanston.
column8: Vic Dong, Elena Gonzalez, Miguel Martinez, Imran Sultan, Alex Gurvich
column17: Wanted Lights off on garage.
column21:
250 folks watched a mostly cloudy sky. We had a few minutes of clearing during the partial eclipse to start, only a few moments of totality, then it started clearing up a lot more the minute totality ended.
Garage lights could not be turned off, which really hampered things. Head electrician said maybe it was possible with enough notice.
Dearborn hosts Sydney, Jay, Alex, Cobi, Ethan, Joe, Anastasia, Ben, and Katie.
https://dailynorthwestern.com/2022/05/17/campus/dearborn-observatory-and-ciera-host-public-viewing-of-total-lunar-eclipse/  We also got some coverage on Fox32 TV and NBC5 TV

column2: Data Science for Public Good Conference
column4: A free, 1-day conference designed for high-schoolers, to learn about how data science and statistics can further the public good.
column8: Jillian Rastinejad, Alex Gurvich, Wynn Jacobson-Galan, Dennis Lee, David Matthews, Joe Michail
column13: K12 Students, Underrepresented Group in STEM
column16: Primary intended audience was high school age girls/non-binary
column17: We didn’t get too many people responding to the feedback form, but here’s one: “It was a really fun webinar, I wish it was a bit more hands on, however I don’t really see a way to do a one day webinar that is hands on and isn’t just telling people word by word how to do something. Over all, I’m glad I had the opportunity to take this and it definitely has me more interested in data science.”

column4: Virtual event for BCSE Summer Scholars designed by CIERA researchers to teach high school students about exoplanets.
column8: Alex Gurvich, Claire Ye, Newlin Weatherford, Lindsay DeMarchi, Chloe Lohmeyer,
column13: K12 Students, Underrepresented Group in STEM
column16: 16 students participated (8 from Round Lake High School and 8 from Lindblom Math & Science Academy)
column17:
Select feedback: 

What is your favorite thing that you learned from this program?... “Learning about how scientists discover planets and some of their characteristics using light. I have never heard this information and it was especially surprising to know that I could figure out what a planet’s composition is using the colors of light.”
“During the 2 weeks of my participation in this program, I was able to learn more about what goes on inside a lab, whether that be proper use of lab equipment or getting a better sense of what it feels like to work with a group researching. Another interesting thing that I learned was about astronomy with CIERA and the process that goes into discovering new solar systems or other stars. Overall, I learned more about STEM related careers and skills for the future!”
“Working with a team on STEM related activities gave me a sense of belonging to the science community and helped me stay motivated in working towards my career. I wasn’t sure what else I could do in STEM besides engineering or being a doctor, but this program helped me explore the diverse careers that STEM offers and reassure me that I want to continue to pursue it in college.”
“I liked learning about space and planets. I also liked that we made a cool discovery and did labs.”
“My favorite thing was learning more about astronomy! I don’t really know much about it, and it isn’t the first thing I think of when I hear “STEM,” but I was pleasantly surprised and the activity was exciting.”
column19: Baxter Center for Science Education (Natalie Bueno, Ashley Walker)

column16: 5-10 kids. Varying levels of astronomy experience. A couple amateur astronomers from local groups, a couple families. Swayed on the older side.
column17: Was well received by attendees. Glad to hear things picking up again. "When is your next event?!"
column21:
A successful return to in-person outreach. 
Lutkin has a nice setup and we can livestream in the future. The lobby was a bit narrow and wouldn't be able to handle all attendees leaving the auditorium at once to do activities. We had a 10-15 minute post-lecture trivia that delayed some attendees from visiting the lobby that worked well.
Lecture went till about 8:10. Folks were gone by 8:50.
The weather the day of the event was thunderstorms and rain during the day, but had subsided by event time. Clouds cancelled the telescope observing. These factors may have hampered attendance. ~100 registered.

column2: UChicago Office of Special Programs Upward Bound Visit
column4: Had an interactive trivia session with students from UChicago's Upward Bound program and also gave them some info on life as an astronomer and what people study at CIERA
column13: K12 Students, Underrepresented Group in STEM
column16: The Upward Bound Program is a federally funded college prep program that supports first-generation, low-income, underserved and under-represented high school students in select neighborhoods and schools.
column17: Students participated well, and most expressed enjoyment of the program. Teacher/chaperone was really excited about pursuing astronomy careers, so I pointed her in the direction of citizen science projects.
column19:

column4: This event looks for the visibility of women in Astronomy and Astrophysics and it is encompassed in the activities created for the 'International Day of Women and Girls in Science'. During the whole day, Spanish women that work on the Astronomy and Astrophysics fields are available to talk about their research with people all over the world (mostly Spain and South America).
column16: >1000. Although the event is aimed for the general public, there are a lot of groups of students from schools and high-schools that connect to our chat. Therefore, it is also an outreach activity for students.
column17: This is the third year we have done this activity and people love it. Every year we have more people connecting and asking questions about our research, our experience as women working on STEM and Astrophysics.
column20: It is a very fulfilling activity since I can talk with a lot of people from different age ranges (from kids that are 10 years old to adults) and backgrounds about my work, Astrophysics and my experience as a woman in science. I had also the opportunity to send motivational messages to young girls that want continue in science but they feel awkward because of the environment (mainly science classes full of boys with only 3-4 girls).
column21: I participate every year

column4: Second event in the series of ongoing open-mic night style events. We did 2 interviews + trivia + a "stump an astronomer" game involving the audience, where we had to describe astronomy concepts in 5 words or less and the audience voted on whose response they liked the most
column8: Alex Gurvich, Chase Kimball, Genevieve Schroeder, Monica Gallegos Garcia
column9: Kate Alexander, Kerry Paterson, Deanne Coppejans, Alicia Rouco Escorial
column17: audience liked trivia and the game we played. they asked lots of questions during the interviews.
column21: It was even more fun than the first event, and we got some more people involved so it was easier to carry out. All-in-all an awesome time!

column4: Inaugural event in the series of ongoing open-mic night style events. We did 2 talks + trivia + Q&A from the audience
column16: Virtual audience tuning in on Youtube
column17: people asked lots of questions, and really enjoyed the trivia, they seemed to enjoy it. One audience member remarked that there was too much "dead air" and too much trivia
column21: It was a great event and we the organizers actually had a lot of fun doing it. We really need more person power to grow it into a viable replacement for Dearborn Astronomer Evenings.

column2: Astronomy on Tap - Hungry Hungry Galaxies
column4: ~Quarterly events at local bars, brewerys, pubs, tap rooms, with trivia (and prizes). Features short talks from members of CIERA (including faculty/post docs/ grad students) and visiting astronomers from other institutions. This particular event featured Cameron Hummels (Caltech) and Evan Schneider (Princeton) and was focused on galaxy formation simulations.
